articles.title: About Me
articles.contents:
Who I Am
My name is Maxwell Lu, and I attend Newton North High School.
Email: maxtlu2005@gmail.com
About This Project
Evaluates over 300,000 samples of participants with or without heart
disease
Compares distinct risk factors and demographics through
straightforward bar charts
Project
Code
Created with the aid of Kane’s Free High School Data
Science Bootcamp

Heart Disease: Notable Risk Factors and Demographics


Home
Research
About
Source
☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Research


  About


  Source

      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020
## # A tibble: 319,795 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          16.6 Yes     No      No           3      30 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  2 No          20.3 No      No      Yes          0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
##  3 No          26.6 Yes     No      No          20      30 No      Male  65-69  
##  4 No          24.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 75-79  
##  5 No          23.7 No      No      No          28       0 Yes     Fema… 40-44  
##  6 Yes         28.9 Yes     No      No           6       0 Yes     Fema… 75-79  
##  7 No          21.6 No      No      No          15       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  8 No          31.6 Yes     No      No           5       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  9 No          26.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
## 10 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Male  65-69  
## # … with 319,785 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
BMIplot <- heart2020 |>
  # calculates mean BMI in entire dataset
  mutate(avg_BMI = mean(BMI)) |>
  # assigns TRUE or FALSE: true = above mean BMI, and vice versa
  mutate(BMI_categorized = if_else(BMI > 28.3254, TRUE, FALSE)) |>
  # these are the only variables we care about
  group_by(BMI_categorized, Race) |>
  # creates percentages of heart disease for many combinations of the variables in the group_by function
  summarize(Percent_HD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = BMI_categorized, y = Percent_HD, fill = Race)) +
  # Aligns the races in a side by side format
  geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") +
  # Gets rid of lines for x axis (since this is a bar chart, they aren't neccesary)
   theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  # changes everything to percentage
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Weight and Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "The overweight in all races aside from American Indian/Alaskan Native experience \nan increase in heart disease",
       x = "Above Mean BMI",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  # changes fonts
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(BMIplot, "BMIplot.rds")

Heart Disease: Notable Risk Factors and Demographics


Home
Research
About
Source
☰

  Research


  About

# Read as CSV the file everytime
heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
genderplot <- heart2020 |>
  # We only care about age and sex in relation to heart disease, nothing else
  group_by(AgeCategory, Sex)|>
  # This creates a percentage of people with heart disease/aka those who answer "Yes" Use .groups = to drop the error message
  summarize(PercentageofHD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  # Making the plot: important note is group = which groups the lines by Sex
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = AgeCategory, y = PercentageofHD, group = Sex, color = Sex)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  # This changes the x-axis marks
 scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("18-24", "30-34", "40-44", "50-54", "60-64", "70-74", "80 or older")) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "The Age Distribution of People With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Risk for Heart Problems Increases With Age",
       x = "Age",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  # Messes with the fonts of the graph
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(genderplot, "genderplot.rds")

Heart Disease: Notable Risk Factors and Demographics


Home
Research
About
Source
☰

  About

heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020 |>
slice_sample(n = 1000)
## # A tibble: 1,000 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          27.0 Yes     No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  2 No          29.5 No      No      No          10       0 No      Male  80 or …
##  3 No          21.8 Yes     No      No           0      30 No      Fema… 18-24  
##  4 No          32.3 No      No      No           0      30 No      Male  50-54  
##  5 No          37.1 Yes     No      No           0       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  6 No          25.4 Yes     No      No           0       0 No      Male  40-44  
##  7 No          39.1 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 30-34  
##  8 No          23.9 Yes     No      No           5      15 No      Fema… 25-29  
##  9 No          23.6 No      No      No           2       0 No      Male  30-34  
## 10 No          26.3 Yes     No      No           2       0 No      Male  70-74  
## # … with 990 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
sample1000 <- heart2020 |>
  slice_sample(n = 1000)
healthplot <- heart2020 |>
  # All we care about is sex and general health in relation to BMI
  group_by(GenHealth, Sex) |>
  # This creates another variable which gives a mean BMI for each combination of sex and general health
  summarize(mean_BMI = mean(BMI), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = GenHealth, y = mean_BMI, fill = Sex)) +
  # Puts males and females side by side
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  # Assigns colors to each bar = pink for female, blue for male
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("lightpink", "cornflowerblue")) +
  # Changes order to x-axis labels
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c("Poor", "Fair", "Good", "Very good", "Excellent")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "The Average Body Mass Index in Five Categories of Health",
       subtitle = "Higher BMIs tend to result in worsened health",
       x = "General Health",
       y = "Average Body Mass Index (BMI)",
       fill = "Gender") +
  # Messes with fonts
      theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(healthplot, "healthplot.rds")

articles.title: Heart Disease: Risk Factors and Demographics
articles.description: Analyzing certain factors that increase susceptibility to cardiovascular issues.
articles.contents:
Introduction
Today, heart disease is the number one cause of death in the United
States. My project investigates the risk factors of heart disease,
including smoking, diabetes, and obesity. I also investigated whether or
not heart disease was more prevalent in a particular race or gender.
As shown below, I found that the majority of individuals with heart
disease in the data were of American Indian/Alaskan Native descent.
Furthermore, I discovered that the heart disease was least prevalent in
the Asian population. In addition, the percentage gap of heart disease
between each group seems to get larger with age.

Heart Disease: Notable Risk Factors and Demographics


Home
Research
About
Source
☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Research


  About


  Source

      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
raceplot <- heart2020 |>
  # age and race are the ones we are investigating in relation to percentage of heart disease
  group_by(AgeCategory, Race)|>
  # we wanted to create a new variable that measured the percentage of heart disease across different combinations of the variables in the group_by function
  summarize(PercentageofHD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = AgeCategory, y = PercentageofHD, group = Race, color = Race)) +
  # connects the lines in the scatterplot
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point() +
  # changes the labels of the x axis
 scale_x_discrete(breaks = c("18-24", "30-34", "40-44", "50-54", "60-64", "70-74", "80 or older")) +
  # changes values in y axis to percentage
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_minimal() +
  # eliminates x axis lines (since bar chart, these aren't necessary)
  theme(panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "The Age Distribution of People With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Risk for Heart Problems Increases With Age",
       x = "Age",
       y = "Percentage Heart Disease") +
  # changes fonts
  theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(raceplot, "raceplot.rds")

articles.title: My Research
articles.description: Examining several graphs relating obesity, smoking, diabetes, gender, and race to heart disease.
articles.contents:
Heart Disease by Gender
The graph below reveals that males have a significantly higher chance
of contracting heart disease than females. Similar to the race plot, the
percentage gap of heart disease increases with age. I hypothesized that
this increase could be due to increased damage over time to the
cardiovascular system from risk factors that were more applicable to
males, such as smoking and obesity.



Interestingly, after investigating the average BMIs of males and
females, I found that there was not a significant deviation between the
average BMIs of both genders. Although higher BMIs tended to result in
health decline, this trend was relatively the same for males and
females.



Impact of BMI and Race
on Heart Disease
On the other hand, after investigating the BMIs of across different
races in relation to the percentage of heart disease, I found that a
higher BMI respondents did indeed contribute a higher percentage of
heart disease than did those with a lower BMI. However, the one
inconsistency I discovered was the American Indian/Alaskan Native
population, in which lower BMI respondents had a higher percentage of
heart disease.



Effects of
Smoking and Diabetes on Heart Disease
Because BMI did not seem to tell a complete story of the factors that
increases heart disease contraction, I analyzed whether or not smoking
and diabetes could be risk factors of heart disease.
In the chart below, each race’s heart disease percentage was analyzed
by smoking and diabetes status. I found that diabetes greatly
contributed to the percentage of heart disease across every race.
Furthermore, the percentage of heart disease in every race was higher in
those who smoked than those who did not.



Conclusion
Through the data provided by Kamil Pytlak, I found that males
contribute to the percentage of heart disease in the dataset far more
than females do. American Indians/Alaskan Natives had the greatest
percentage of heart disease among all other races, which was likely due
to increased smoking habits.
Finding ways to reduce poor smoking habits and investigate why they
arise, especially in the American Indian/Alaskan Native population, may
help decrease the chance of getting heart disease.

Heart Disease: Notable Risk Factors and Demographics


Home
Research
About
Source
☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Research


  About


  Source

      
  










heart2020 <- read_csv(file = "heart_2020_cleaned.csv")
## Rows: 319795 Columns: 18
## ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
## Delimiter: ","
## chr (14): HeartDisease, Smoking, AlcoholDrinking, Stroke, DiffWalking, Sex, ...
## dbl  (4): BMI, PhysicalHealth, MentalHealth, SleepTime
## 
## ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
## ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
heart2020
## # A tibble: 319,795 × 18
##    HeartDis…¹   BMI Smoking Alcoh…² Stroke Physi…³ Menta…⁴ DiffW…⁵ Sex   AgeCa…⁶
##    <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
##  1 No          16.6 Yes     No      No           3      30 No      Fema… 55-59  
##  2 No          20.3 No      No      Yes          0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
##  3 No          26.6 Yes     No      No          20      30 No      Male  65-69  
##  4 No          24.2 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 75-79  
##  5 No          23.7 No      No      No          28       0 Yes     Fema… 40-44  
##  6 Yes         28.9 Yes     No      No           6       0 Yes     Fema… 75-79  
##  7 No          21.6 No      No      No          15       0 No      Fema… 70-74  
##  8 No          31.6 Yes     No      No           5       0 Yes     Fema… 80 or …
##  9 No          26.4 No      No      No           0       0 No      Fema… 80 or …
## 10 No          40.7 No      No      No           0       0 Yes     Male  65-69  
## # … with 319,785 more rows, 8 more variables: Race <chr>, Diabetic <chr>,
## #   PhysicalActivity <chr>, GenHealth <chr>, SleepTime <dbl>, Asthma <chr>,
## #   KidneyDisease <chr>, SkinCancer <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
## #   ¹​HeartDisease, ²​AlcoholDrinking, ³​PhysicalHealth, ⁴​MentalHealth,
## #   ⁵​DiffWalking, ⁶​AgeCategory
## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows, and `colnames()` to see all variable names
smokeplot <- heart2020 |>
  # Creates new variable that measures smoking status
  mutate(Smoker_categorized = if_else(Smoking == "Yes", "Smokes", "Does Not Smoke")) |>
  select(Race, Smoker_categorized, HeartDisease, Diabetic) |>
  # These are the ones we care about
  group_by(Race, Smoker_categorized, Diabetic) |> 
  # This creates a list of percentages of heart disease with all kinds of combinations from the variables of the group_by function
  summarize(Percent_HD = mean(HeartDisease == "Yes"), .groups = "drop") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Race, y = Percent_HD, fill = Diabetic)) +
  # Flips bar chart from up bar chart to side chart
  coord_flip() +
  geom_col(color = "black") +
  # Creates two plots: one of people who don't smoke, and one for people who do
  facet_wrap(~Smoker_categorized) +
  # changes everything y axis label percentage
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  theme_light() +
  # gets rid of y axis line (since this is bar chart we don't need it)
   theme(panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()) +
  labs(title = "Percent of Smoking and Non-Smoking \nIndividuals from Each Race With Heart Disease",
       subtitle = "Individuals with Diabetes are more susceptible to heart issues",
       y = "Percent with Heart Disease in Each Race",
       x = "Race") +
  # Messes with fonts in graph
    theme(plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          plot.subtitle = element_text(face = "italic"),
          axis.text = element_text(face = "bold"), 
          axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold"),
          axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold"))
write_rds(smokeplot, "smokeplot.rds")

articles.title: Source
articles.description: All data pulled from cleaned 2020 CDC dataset.
articles.contents:
Kaggle dataset: “Personal Key Indicators of Heart Disease.” (Pytlak 2020)
For more information about this topic, visit Pytlak’s Personal
Heart Disease Predictor.



Pytlak, Kamil. 2020. “Personal Key Indicators of Heart
Disease.” Kaggle. https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/kamilpytlak/personal-key-indicators-of-heart-disease.
